content.description: This is a great route that contains face, crack, and overhang climbing at its best. The face holds are good, the crack on the left of the overhang is a hand crack, the crack at the bottom is a finger crack. The pitch can start on the face which makes things easier. The route holds good protection. The crux starts at the overhanging roof.
content.protection: We used 4 pieces of protection. Small cams should work well.
content.location: Park the car at the gravel parking space, the route is about 20 meters from the top of the whole crag.

content.description: This is a really fun climb for a top rope 5.9. It is immediately to the left of West Crack on the West side of Nemesis Tower.
content.protection: Nuts seem to work really well for top roping this climb.

content.description: This is a large corner crack that runs right up the southwest side of Nemesis Tower.
content.protection: You can either top rope this or boulder this. That is a decision that is up to you . If you top rope this nuts come in really handy.

content.description:
This route is located right (southwest) of

Gracie's Dihedral

along the Crack Wall.  Approach the top of the climb by walking along the ridgeline from the parking area.  One can reach the base of the climb via an access gully north of the

S-Crack

area to the north.  This route is found in

Front Range Topropes

by Fred Knapp.
content.protection: Longs slings can be used to toprope this route.

content.description: Climb the west-facing wall up pockets and slots, and use a really good, right handed sidepull.
content.protection: None.
content.location:
It is left of

Unknown Mini-Great Roof

and downhill from

WTF

area. This is the last route before there is a section that turns low angle with lots of lichen on it. Look at the photos.

content.description: Climb the small roof up through s series of very small roofs on good rock. There are lots of horizontal ledges.
content.protection: Various sizes.
content.location: There are two roughly parallel cracks about 8-10' apart from each on a west-facing section of the wall. The crack on the left is around 10a. This one on the right is 5.8-ish. There is another corner crack to the right of these two parallel cracks.

content.description: Climb the right-facing corner. The crux seems to be about 20' up.
content.protection: Various sizes.
content.location: Go downhill from the parking lot past the 25' tall bouldering areas and past the first 2-3 taller areas with good rock. Look at the photo.

content.description: Climb the right-facing corner to the roof, then undercling your way right out the horizontal roof. Then go to the top. Good technique can make the vertical crack, especially the top of it under the roof restful; without technique, you are likely to get pretty pumped. The underclings are good. There is one more physical move at the end of the roof as you pull up and around the roof.
content.protection: Various sizes.
content.location:
It is downhill past the

WTF

area. Look at the photo.

content.description: At the arete, climb the jugs to the roof, and make a powerful move to get over the roof. This is a one move wonder. Once you're over the roof, it's pretty mellow.
content.protection: Not sure.
content.location:
It climbs the arete 10' left of

WTF

, a 5.8 corner. Walk down from the parking lot past the long section of 25' bouldering traverses and upclimbs. This area with

WTF

and other routes is the first area with 35' routes on decent rock. There is a small, flat, sandy belay area at the bottom.

content.description: This route begins on some jugs and moves up through the face to the very obvious finger crack that goes through a 2' roof. There is another 10' of climbing after the roof. The crux is getting over the roof to a good, horizontal ledge. It has very good quality rock, minus the bottom 8-10 feet of white choss.
content.protection:
There is very good gear once at the roof and above, finger-size to hand-sized pieces. To protect the bottom, there may be placements to be had in the face, or you may have to put some gear in the corner to the left, the bottom section of

WTF

, and then move up and right to the roof.
content.location: The route goes up through the obvious finger crack in the middle of the face to the right of WTF, 5.8. WTF is the nice looking right facing dihedral crack. This little wall has the first set of nice looking taller routes as you walk down hill from the upper parking lot past the boulder traverse areas. There is a decent flat area at the bottom for belaying.

content.description:
From the base of the

5.8 Corner Crack

(the left of the two corner cracks), look for some small pockets, slots, and crimps that go out, up, and left from the crack.
content.protection: None.
content.location:
This is down the hill from the

WTF

area. This route is on a west-facing wall. See the photos.

content.description: This route ascends the arete. Begin on jugs, and move to a small 2' ledge. Here lies the crux, and you do some moves to get onto the small ledge. It is mellow face climbing from there to the top. This is a 2 move wonder.
content.protection: Minimal pro if at all.
content.location:
This route is a few feet to the right of the obvious finger crack that goes through the 2' roof, which is another few feet to the right of

WTF

, a right-facing, 5.8 dihedral crack. This is the first decent area of good rock and quality routes as you come downhill from the parking lot. From the parking lot, walk down hill past the 20' bouldering traverse areas to a place on the trail that is flat that is big enough for a few people to hang out and belay.

content.description: This route is worth the time. It is short with great movement. It takes gear about halfway up and then again at the top. This makes for a good highball with a pad as well.
content.protection: Two stoppers or cams.

content.description: This route has fun slapping up a rounded arete on small feet. It needs a few more climbs to clean up.
content.protection: Setting up a top rope up top with a few nuts is easily done.
content.location:
To the left of

Final Finger

, start as you would for

Final Finger

, then traverse left to the rounded arete, and crank on up to the lip.

content.description: Climb the left of two corner cracks. This one goes up through a small chimney at the top. Watch out for loose rock on the ledges up there and rat poop.
content.protection: Various sizes.
content.location:
From the parking lot, go downhill past the 25' tall bouldering areas to the taller cliffs with good rock. This is not far further downhill from the

WTF

area.

content.description: Climb the crack in the left-facing corner.
content.protection: Various sizes.
content.location:
Go downhill from the parking lot past the 25' tall, bouldering traverse areas. Once the cliff gets taller and the quality of the rock gets better, you'll get to the

WTF

area that has a decent, small flat belay area. Further downhill about 30 feet or so, you will find this area with the cracks.

content.description: The climbing is fairly consistent up this left-facing corner with a steep move over a very small roof at the bottom.
content.protection: Various sizes of gear.
content.location:
This is downhill from the

WTF

area about 30'. From the parking lot, go downhill past the 25' bouldering areas. Once you get to the first set of climbs that are taller and have quality rock, go just a little further where the trail tightens down a little.

content.description:
This is the right edge of the roof behind the tree, 25 yards from the top. Bump out to the end the switch your feet and heel hook the prow.

Per

Jed Smith

: this is an awesome climb that starts under a large roof and climbs out and around the face of the overhang. Start in the crack immediately to the left of a large chockstone with an X on it (very, very loose). From the crack, make a large move to an excellent ledge on the right side of the roof. Then pull around the face onto another jug. The crux is getting your feet up and pulling to hard-to-see jugs and crimps. The climb tops out underneath the canopy of a ponderosa pine. Downclimb the tree or top out and walk around.

Eds. Two submissions were combined here to avoid duplication.
content.protection:
Top rope or crash pad with a good spot.

Per

Jed Smith

: the landing is not very flat, and you can wind up horizontal if you use a very solid heel hook at the crux. Two pads should be enough with a spotter.
content.location:
Per

Jed Smith

: this is located under the first large overhang, approximately 40 yards down from the parking area. There is a large ponderosa pine tree directly west of the climb.

content.description: Begin the problem down the ridge at the end of the first band of rocks, this is the Torture Chamber.  The problem is a continuous, juggy traverse up the ridge to the right keeping the feet as high as possible, a long traverse without a doubt.  Variations exist, probably all with a FA by Gill too, using smaller holds for the hands and keeping the feet higher.  All the variations make the problem more difficult.
content.protection: A pad and a spotter can be helpful, but not at all necessary as the route never is more then a few feet above the ground.

climbs.name: Some boulder problem with a crack

content.description: This problem is about 10 to 15 feet to the left of the start of the torture chamber traverse. It traverses left into a roof crack out and around and tops out by climbing straight up a crack.
content.protection: A good spotter is probably a really good idea. This is a nasty spot to take a fall.

content.description:
This is a nice route that follows the line in the picture. It's a 5.7, so it doesn't have a crux

per se

. The route goes straight up and then to the left of the roof "

The Roofus

, 5.9". The holds are good and solid.
content.protection: If you want to lead it, you can find 2 places to fix pro (small cams), but it's easy to set up a top rope anchor at the top of it, and it has an easy access to them without climbing.
content.location:
The route is located right next to "

WTF

". Park the car at the parking area, follow the trail, and it's the first wall with a roof after the boulders.

content.description: There are two cruxes, one at the bottom and one at the top. This is one of my favorite climbs at the Torture Chamber.
content.protection: Cams come in real handy to toprope this climb.
content.location: This is a great crack shaped like an S at the far bottom of The Torture Chamber.

content.description:
Start the route just like the "

Sagas 50

" until you get to the roof (Roofus). Once you get to the roof, go straight up the roof without going left or right of it. The Roofus is the crux of the route. There is only 1 good hold on the roof itself, the rest are slopey. There is a loose and moving hand hold on the right side, but it can be used gently. It is a very interesting route that requires a lot of upper body strength, but finding foot holds (which is not easy) is the key.
content.protection: We would recommend to top rope this route, because the roof is hard and there is only 1 spot to place a small and iffy piece of pro way below the roof. So falling is highly not recommended.
content.location:
The route is located right next to "

WTF

".

Park the car at the parking area, follow the trail, and it's the first wall with a roof after the boulders. It is in the same area as "

Sagas 50

" and "

Dos Gorditos

".

content.description: This overhanging hand crack with jugs offers quality climbing, with the crux about 10-15 feet up.
content.protection: It's low enough to boulder, but you could practice leading or set up a toprope.
content.location:
About 20 yards east of

WTF

is a formation with three well-featured cracks.

content.description:
Climb up the arete right of

Cracky Face

using thin holds and friction, avoiding the cracks.
content.protection: A toprope.

content.description: Start using the crack system under the left roof. Once you reach the arete traverse to the right crack system by pulling around a small arete. Then climb to right crack to just beneath the roofs. Pull up between the roofs to top out. The crux is the top out where the feet run out. Good variety of movements and features for such a short climb at this grade.
content.protection: A few small-medium cams will be fine to lead it or a top rope can be easily set up with gear.
content.location: About 30 feet east (downhill) from Nemesis Tower, look for the two roofs that look a little like a mouth.

content.description: Start sitting underneath the northwest arete, and grab the arete with one hand and the sloping rail with the other. Crank through a burly start followed by easy movement in the middle. The top is protected by one last challenging move.
content.protection: A pad or two.
content.location: It is west of the Nemesis Tower on the distinct, tall, triangular boulder and downhill from the cliff band.

content.description: This is a top rope problem that ascends the northeast face of the Nemesis Tower. This is a difficult line. About three quarter's of the way up is the difficult crux.
content.protection: Bring nuts for top rope protection.

content.description: Head towards the appealing crack, then proceed to be disappointed, and head left up the face.
content.protection: A TR.

content.description:
Several very good boulder problems lie immediately left of the obvious roof described as an unnamed Gill problem in this guide.  They all start on the north side of the roof.  I'll describe them left to right.

1) V0- Left side of roof, left of the two trees, and about 10 feet right of the obvious downclimb.  Long reach or dyno to the big jugs.  Edge on good holds to the top.

2) V0 -- About 6 feet right of #1, and near the leftmost of the two trees.  Up the center of the roof, then move left to positive crimps and up the easy face.

3) V0+ -- A few feet farther right, between the two trees.  Reach for the big crack.  Crank your feet onto the sloping lip.

4) V?  -- Harder variations abound on the right.
content.protection: Crash pad.
content.location:
Torture Chamber, about 25 yards east of the

Torture Chamber Traverse

and immediately opposite the giant roof.

content.description:
This route is immediately right (southwest) of

S-Crack

and left (northeast) of

Unnamed 5.9

.  Access the top of the route by walking along the ridgeline from the parking area.  Access the base of the climb via an access gully north of the area.
content.protection: A few nuts can be used to set up a toprope.

content.description:
This is yet another great crack that is to the immediate left of

Cracky Face

. The three climb's in this immediate area (

S Crack

,

Cracky Face

, and, Final Finger are excellent climbs.
content.protection: Cams and webbing are good for top roping this climb.

content.description: Sit start low on the obvious undercling jug, move through pinches, crimps and slopers until you match the plate, then double clutch the lip.
content.protection: 2 pads, and a slider is helpful for the start.
content.location: Walk down the trail, and the boulder will be obvious on your left right above Nemesis Tower.

content.description:
The route starts just like the the "

Sagas 50

".

After a few moves, start moving right to the right, vertical rock face. This is where the crux begins. The holds are super tiny and slopey, very little foot holds. The crux moves are truly 5.10b/c. After those few moves, the climbing eases up and you finish at the top.
content.protection: If you want to lead it, you can find 1 place to fix a pro (small cam), but it's easy to set up a top rope anchor at the top of it, and it has an easy access to the top.
content.location:
The route is located right next to "

WTF

".

Park the car at the parking area, follow the trail, and it's the first wall with a roof after the boulders.

climbs.name: Death Arête
climbs.fa: Timy Fairfield and Joe Crotty, October, 1987

content.description: Pull on some decent crimpers with high feet at the bottom. Hit a good mail slot, then pull onto a slopy ledge, and finish it up.
content.protection: A couple big pads as landing is subpar.
content.location:
It ascends the arête just right of

Gracie's Dihedral

.

content.description:
This is a thin crack that is just to the immediate left of

S Crack

.
content.protection: We used cams in a crack and webbing as a sling to protect this climb.

content.description:
This route is immediately left (northeast) of

S-Crack

and right (southwest) of

Cracky Face

.  Access the top of the route by walking along the ridgeline from the parking area.  There is a gully just north of this area that can be used to downclimb to the base of the climb.  The name of the route is found in

Front Range Topropes

by Fred Knapp.
content.protection: Nuts were used to set up a top rope.

content.description:
Start 6 feet right of '

Unnamed 5.9

'. Climb thoughtful moves through a lower bulge, and enjoy the crux pulling the final exit moves.
content.protection: Small gear.

content.description: Scramble up the the small roof in the choss band, then follow the corner crack to the top.
content.protection: Bring a hand-sized cam or two and some small gear.
content.location: Follow the base off the ridge down from the parking lot for about 200 feet to the tall section of the choss band, and you'll see two large, opposed dihedrals. Climb the one on the right side.
